contents.name: Chapter 1: The Setting
headers: A Physical Connection to the Gods

entries.name: Everything Under Pelor's Light
entries: When the secrets of aetherflight were rediscovered, the Known World changed forever. The ubiquity of air travel has made the continents of Erathis an interconnected world, and a nation's concern now ends neither at the water's edge nor the sky's limit, but at the edge of the Pelor's light. Orbiting Erathis are two moons: Sehanine and Ioun (ion). Sehanine is well-known as the ancestral elven homeland and gate to the Feywild and Shadowfell. Ioun orbits farther away and is best known for the arcane potency that manifests around it as well as those who travel there to study it.

Farther beyond, Port Avandra, named wantingly in honor of the goddess of freedom and luck, serves as the final bastion of civilization. Beyond that, skirting the furthest reaches of Pelor's light, lies Tharizdun's Disc -- an asteroid belt of ill omen and great riches. Wrecked hulls of those who went mad amongst the rocks serve as warnings to those daring to delve further into the Black. Stories of what lies beyond warn of behemoth creatures with unfathomable length, but such stories are rare and often mere testimonies of the mad who lost sight of Pelor's light.

entries.name: A Physical Connection to the Gods
entries: Gods in this world are no mere stories, nor are they distant spectators. The gods are very real but make their presence known in different ways. Some, such as Pelor -- god of sun, summer, and time -- are believed to manifest themselves in parts of the world, such as the Sun itself. Others like Erathis -- god of civilization, invention, and law -- have even been known to wander the realm in a mortal form and interact with its inhabitants.

The various planes are also very present in this world. Portals to the Shadowfell are plentiful on the dark side of Sehanine, while crossings to the Feywild can be found on bright side. Gates to the Elemental planes can be found on Erathis, although finding one is no easy task. And, if one travels far beyond Pelor's reach, they will eventually find themselves in the Astral plane.
This setting uses the {@table A Sample Pantheon; Dawn War Deities|DMG|Dawn War} pantheon.

entries.name: Wait, Where's My Helmet?
entries: What is this, a fantasy game??

When a ship moves from breathable atmosphere to the Aether, an air pocket clings to it like a bubble. These air bubbles are large enough to sustain the crew of a ship for about 30 days. Any longer and a ship or its crew will need additional equipment to keep its crew breathing. This air pocket is not 'poppable,' and can only be removed by consuming all the air inside or by powerful magic. Even if a ship is destroyed, air will still cling to the larger debris. When a ship enters a celestial object's atmosphere, their bubble will dissipate, joining with the larger atmosphere.

Gravity, whether on Erathis, an asteroid, or even a ship, is exerted with the same force. Although gravity still applies where there is no atmosphere (such as some asteroids in Tharizdun's Disc), a good rule of thumb is that as long as you're within an object's atmosphere you'll be affected by its gravity. Where the gravity pulls is what would make sense in atmosphere: For ships, if you fall off the side while in the Aether, you'll keep falling down until you exit the air bubble. At that point, you're outside of its gravitational influence. If outside of atmosphere, suffocation rules apply and a creature takes 1 cold damage per turn.

If outside of any gravitational pull, objects can move only by pushing or pulling against a fixed object or surface within reach (such as a wall or a ceiling), which allows it to move as if it were climbing.

entries.name: Visibility in the aether
entries: In clear conditions, visibility is essentially unlimited, however one's ability to spot other ships against the backdrop of the void is still limited by perception. The table below details the approximate difficulty of spotting ships at various distances.
A creature using a spyglass and actively on watch (i.e. not passively perceiving) has a +5 bonus to the roll.
Hazards and conditions in the aether can impact visibility as well.

entries.name: Race Options
entries: The following race options are permitted for this setting. Some races have setting-specific considerations to take into account when making your character, which you can read more about in Chapter 4. When assigning racial ASI bonuses, you can use the {@variantrule customizing your origin|tce|Ability Score Increases} rule from TCE.

entries.name: {@filter PHB|races|source=PHB}
entries: All races are permitted.

entries.name: {@filter EEPC|races|source=EEPC}
entries: All races are permitted.

entries.name: {@filter MTF|races|source=MTF}
entries: The elf, tiefling, and gnome subraces are permitted.

entries.name: {@filter VGM|races|source=VGM}
entries: All races are permitted.

entries.name: {@filter ERLW |races|source=ERLW}
entries: Changelings and shifters are permitted.

entries.name: {@filter MOT|races|source=MOT}
entries: All MOT races except centaurs are permitted.

entries.name: {@filter GGR|races|source=GGR}
entries: Loxodons are permitted.

entries.name: Backgrounds
entries: The following section details character creation pertaining to backgrounds. There are some reskinned setting-specific backgrounds, but also feel free to use PHB, GoS, or custom backgrounds for your character.

entries.name: The Importance of Tools
entries: In some settings or campaigns, tool proficiencies might take a backseat to skills. On a ship in the aether, however, a tool proficiency can be the difference between life and death. Having someone on your crew with the know-how to man the helm of a ship, repair a broken hull or tattered sail, or triangulate your position in the stars is what makes a great crew. Consider picking up a tool proficiency in your character's background.

items: {@b Vehicles (Water).} The ability to proficiently steer a waterfaring vessel is extended to ships that traverse the aether. Piloting a ship, much like driving a car, primarily requires Intelligence and Wisdom. Intelligence to understand the mechanics of your ship, and Wisdom to have the situational awareness and foresight to see the right course of action to take. Dexterity will also be valuable on occasion, especially in the cases of avoiding a fast-moving asteroid or a performing difficult maneuver.
{@b {@item Artisan's Tools|PHB}.} Almost every set of artisan's tools can find use on a ship, and many of them are nigh necessities.

{@b {@item Carpenter's Tools|PHB}.} The signature tools of a shipwright, a set of carpenter's tools allows one to make patchwork repairs on a ship. You can use carpenter's tools to repair a ship by a number of hull points equal to your proficiency modifier. You must have appropriate materials to make the repairs, and once you repair a ship in this way, it can't be repaired in this way again until it is repaired at a shipyard.
{@b {@item Smith's Tools|PHB}.} Smith's tools function similarly to carpenter's tools but for ships equipped with metal plating.

{@b {@item Jeweler's Tools|PHB}.} Gems in this setting hold latent magical energy, and knowing the correct value of gems is a vital skill when dealing with gemforges and any bedazzled implements you might encounter.

{@b {@item Cook's Utensils|PHB}.} Cooking meals with raw ingredients rather than expending rations is cheaper, lighter, and only doable with cook's utensils. When you have proficiency with these tools, you can cook meals for a whole ship. The amount of raw ingredients necessary to sustain a crew can be found in the {@book Food and Water|PHB|8|Food and Water} section of the PHB.
{@b {@item Weaver's Tools|PHB}.} Having weaver's tools let you repair sails outside of port. If sails are your only mode of propulsion, these tools could be the difference between life and death.
{@b {@item Navigator's Tools|PHB}.} Proficiency in these tools will help you figure out where you are in the system and where you need to go.
{@b {@item Forgery Kit|PHB}.} If you choose to take the less-than-legal path, the ability to forge documents could be very valuable.

entries.name: Setting-Specific Background Features
entries: The following background features may be used.

items.name: Shipwright feature: 'I'll Patch It!'
items.entry: Provided you have carpenter's tools and wood (or, if dealing with a metal hull, smith's tools) you can perform repairs on a ship outside of a shipyard. When you use this ability, you can restore a number of hull points equal to your Intelligence + proficiency modifier over the course of 8 hours. Once you repair a ship in this way, it can't be repaired in this way again until it is repaired at a shipyard.

items.name: Smuggler feature: 'False Flag'
items.entry: You have the know-how to create a false identity for yourself and your ship. You gain advantage on ability checks to disguise a ship. Additionally, you can forge documents, including official papers and personal letters as long as you have seen an example of the kind of document or the handwriting you are trying to copy.

entries.name: {@background Alliance Marine (Soldier)|AETH}
entries: The Alliance marines have been your life for as long as you could hold a sword. You might have served on airships and fought off invaders on the outer edge of Erathis or been a member of the infamous Vanguard during the Sehanine War. Or perhaps you were just a customs enforcer at a port. Whatever your story, you have good standing with the Alliance marines and will find respect amongst them.

entries.name: {@background Flame of Pelor (Acolyte)|AETH}
entries: Some who worship Pelor are chosen to leave their temples and travel beyond the farthest reaches of Pelor's light to spread his virtue and illuminate even the darkest regions of the aether. These acolytes are the Flames of Pelor, an order whose mission is well-known throughout the Known World. Your Shelter the Faithful feature will grant you welcome in any good-aligned deity's temple.

entries.name: {@background Scholar of the Iounian Order (Sage)|AETH}
entries: The Iounian order is a secluded organization of scholars, mages, and clerics of Ioun dedicated to unearthing and understanding the secrets of the Known World. As a scholar in this order, you have dedicated yourself to this goal and now find yourself traveling the lands in search of ancient and forgotten places, artifacts, and knowledge.

entries.name: {@background Witness of Tharizdun (Hermit)|AETH}
entries: You've delved deeper into Tharizdun's Disc than anyone else and somehow lived to tell the tale. You saw something in there that not even Pelor's light could reach and it's changed you. Perhaps you found something you weren't meant to see, or perhaps something found you. Whatever you saw, it's your choice whether to share your discovery or keep it a secret.

entries.name: Feats
entries: The following feats have been modified for the setting.

items: Nevermind

entries.name: Ship Movement
entries: In combat, a ship's movement speed is determined by its mode of propulsion. If power is lost on a power-dependent propulsion, speed becomes 0. On a hexgrid battlemap where 1 hex represents 100 feet, one movement is equal to one hex.

On long range travel, a ship can generally attain double its combat speed while moving on a constant heading. A ship can't become exhausted, nor can it choose to move faster, although it can move at a slower pace. Long Range Travel between major locations is determined in days.

entries.name: Ship Power
entries: All ships must have at least one power source, although most are equipped with an auxiliary as back-up. Below are the different types of common power sources. A maximum of 2 power sources can be installed at one time on a ship, to prevent any electrical infetterence.
{@filter Ship Power|vehicles|source=AETH|upgrade type=ship upgrade, power}.

entries.name: Ship Propulsion
entries: Propulsion is vital equipment on a ship and determine the speed and maneuvering capability of a ship. Both powered and unpowered propulsion exists, and many work differently depending on whether in air or aether. A maximum of 2 propulsion types can be installed on a ship but only one may be used at any time.
{@filter Ship Propulsion|vehicles|source=AETH|upgrade type=SHP:M}.

entries.name: Ship Modifications
entries: {@filter Ship Modifications|vehicles|source=AETH|upgrade type=SHP:O; Ship Upgrade, Room; SHP:H; SHP:F} are additions to ships that can be installed or uninstalled at a shipyard. Modifications come in many forms, shapes, and sizes -- from additional equipment to altered hulls to magical figureheads.

entries.name: Hulls
entries: A {@filter ship's hull|vehicles|source=AETH|upgrade type=SHP:H} is often one of its most defining feature, and many a legendary ship are well-known by their unique hull. A ship can only have one type of hull equipped at a time.

entries.name: Rooms
entries: When a voyage might last weeks on end, a ship becomes your flying home away from home. {@filter Custom rooms|vehicles|source=AETH|upgrade type=Ship Upgrade, Room} allow you to continue your downtime activities while away from port. Keep in mind that some rooms like the Arcane Library or Assassin's Garden require components that likely won't be available at a regular shipyard.

entries.name: Figureheads
entries: Much like a ship's hull, its figurehead is an iconic face of the ship. {@filter Most figureheads|vehicles|source=AETH|upgrade type=SHP:F} in this world have magical capabilities, ranging from useful utility to combat enhancements that can turn the tide of battle. Only one figurehead can be equipped at a time.

entries.name: Landing Capabilities
entries: A ship may have landing capability, although such a feature is not guaranteed. The ability to land in water is most common, with surface landing less common. Larger ships may omit landing capabilities entirely, opting instead to stay above and send skiffs to the surface. Aftermarket landing gear may be installed for water or land at a port. The common rate is approximately 75g/Ton.

entries.name: Cargo Space
entries: A ship's cargo space is measured in tons and serves as an abstraction of the limitations of what a ship can reasonably hold, in terms of both weight and space. Most ships generally have half their tonnage in cargo space, although ships may have more or less depending on their intended role. Cargo space is necessary for storing fuel, rations, ammunition, loot, and even smaller craft.

entries.name: Towing
entries: A ship with Anchors and Tethers may tow another ship by grappling them as long as the towed ship's propulsion is disabled. A ship can move at half-speed while towing.

entries.name: Repairing Ships
entries: Almost any shipyard can repair ships and armament. The cost of repair is:

entries.name: Purchasing a Ship
entries: The price of a ship generally doesn't take into account any propulsion, power, weaponry, or modifications installed. The common price of a ship hull is:

entries.name: Ship Combat
entries: Ship combat is measured within a hex-grid and has its own set of rules distinct from basic D&D combat, although the core principles remain the same. One hex on a ship-combat battlemat represents 100 feet.

entries.name: The Flow of Combat
entries: On each ship's turn, a ship may make a Move action and an Attack action, in either order, however an one must be completed before another can begin. A ship may circumvent this limitation by performing a 'fly-by' maneuver.
Ship combat continues until one side is boarded, destroyed, or surrenders.
There are no attacks of opportunity from ship movement.

entries.name: Captain Commands
entries: {@b Volley.} When the Volley order is given, all crew prepared to fire their armament make their attack action. The captain can choose to have this order be implicit, normally indicated by an {@b 'Open Fire'} command.
{@b Fly-by Maneuver.} The Captain must declare this feature before the ship takes any actions. You may move between attacks, but all ship armament attacks this turn have disadvantage.

entries.name: Boarding
entries: When a ship is grappled, crew from either ship may begin boarding the other. At this point, until the grapple is broken, ship-to-ship combat is ended and crew combat begins on a battlemat with both ships side-by-side. {@b Whichever side initiated the grapple now gets to move first in crew combat, regardless of ship initiative.}

Just as in conventional D&D, each round in crew combat lasts 6 seconds. If either ship pulls away from the other, after 1 crew combat round, ship combat is reengaged and in crew are still onboard after that time.

When two ships are docked with eachother, grappled or not, crew from either ships may board the other. If either ship pulls away, ship combat is reengaged after one round (i.e., any crew still on a hostile ship has 1 turn to get back to their own).

entries.name: Crewmen in Combat
entries: On the ship's turn in initiative, it's up to the crew to take actions that make the ship function. This is done by manning the relevant stations.

items: {@b Helm}. To move the ship, someone must be manning the helm. The crewperson manning the helm must use their action to make the ship take its move action.

{@b Armament}. When a Volley is ordered, the crew manning armament use their action to attack with the armament. Ships can make as many attacks as there are manned armment, but all attacks must be made at once.
{@b Spotter}. Without a spotter to keep track of enemy activity via Wisdom (Perception) checks, you won't be sure what's happening on the other ship's deck during ship combat.
{@b Other}. Many ships have unique features or equipment that must be used by crew.

entries: During ship combat, each crewmember still has an action, bonus action, and movement.

items: {@b Movement} of crew members is abstracted in ship combat. You can use your movement to move to any place on the ship, and this can be done before or after you take any other type of action.
{@b Bonus Actions} can be used for any feature you have as per normal.
{@b Actions} are the main method of interacting with ship stations, although they may also be used for conventional actions as well.

entries.name: Initative
entries: Initiative is determined by one person on each ship, normally the captain, rolling a d20 and adding the ship's movement bonus. The entire crew of a ship moves on their ship's turn in initiative.

entries.name: Damaging Ships
entries: Crew can only damage a ship when they are on the ship itself or, in the case of ranged attacks, with magic or ammunition that deals bludgeoning damage. Ships are
When they deal damage, the ship loses 1 Hull Point for every 10 Hit Points dealt, rounded down. Any attack that deals less than 10 points has no effect.

entries.name: Critical Hits
entries: When a ship's armament scores a critical hit you can roll on the {@table ship crit|AETH|Ship Crit} table to determine an extra effect on top of doubled damage dice.
Furthermore, whenever a ship is reduced to 50% hull points (rounded down) they must roll on the table. If a critical hit brings a ship below 50% hull points, they must roll twice on the table.

entries.name: Breaking Apart
entries: When a ship hits 0 hull points it will begin to break apart. For every 10 tons of ship, roll a d6 to determine the amount of atmosphere-retaining pieces that remain. If a player is on a ship as it breaks apart, they must make a DC15 DEX saving throw to determine if they are able to hold onto a piece of atmo-retaining hull. On a fail they're ejected into the aether.
Once in space, suffocation rules apply and the creature can move only by pushing or pulling against, or climbing along a fixed object or surface within reach, similar to the Levitation spell.

entries.name: Armaments
entries: Although most ship battles end in a crew-on-crew battle, the war fought through ship-mounted armament is often what determines the winner. Armaments have both a hit point damage die and a hull point damage die. Hit points apply when hitting creatures, while the hull point dice are for hits on ships or other targets with hull points (such as gargantuan creatures).

Armament systems require a stock of supplies to use them, stored in cargo. So long as an applicable supply of ammunition is on the ship, an armament may fire once per turn, unless otherwise specified.

By default, an armament attack will aim only at the general ship hull. To target a specific part of the ship (such as crew, armament, or other systems), the attacker can do so with disadvantage. Any attempts to target specific ship parts beyond their armament's non-disadavantaged range is not possible.

entries.name: Weapon Bays
entries: Armament can only be used while in a weapon bay. A ship has a number of weapon bays equal to half the total cargo space of your ship (rounded down), so if the maximum cargo capacity of a ship is 10 tons, that ship has 2 weapon bays.

entries.name: Ballista
entries: Ballistae fire javelins with great force and accuracy. All ballistae have the Turreted property, meaning they can fire in any direction regardless of ship heading.

items: {@object Light Ballista|AETH|Light Ballistae} do not suffer disadvantage when targeting crew of another ship.
{@object Heavy Ballista|AETH|Heavy Ballistae} have the ability to fire other types of ammo such as harpoons or custom-headed projectiles.

entries.name: {@object Catapult |AETH|Catapult}
entries: Catapults launch large stones at great force from a fixed position, making for ideal anti-ship weaponry. A non-turreted catapult can target any ship in its range in a cone from its position.
{@object Mangonel|AETH|Mangonels} are a smaller form of catapult, launching a smaller projectile and in turn requiring fewer crew to operate.

entries.name: {@object Jettison|AETH|Jettison}
entries: Jettisons are similar to catapults but launch a bundle of shrapnel as anti-crew projectiles. Ideal against crowded decks but ineffective against hulls. Creatures caught in the jettison's area of effect must make a DEX saving throw, taking no damage on a save.

entries.name: {@object Light Cannon|AETH|Light Cannon}
entries: Cannons as feared by the enemy as they are by their own crew. Terrifyingly powerful in combat both against crew and hull, cannons have a troublesome tendency to explode when destroyed, severely damaging both ship and crew around the area and rendering the armament unrepairable.

entries.name: Ram
entries: Rams are large devices mounted to the front of a ship, taking place of the figurehead spot. To use a ram, the attacking ship must move 1 hex in a straight line before entering the same space of the ship to be rammed. The damage dealt by the ram is based on the weight of the ship.
Three types of rams can be equipped:

items: {@object Blunt Ram|AETH|Blunt Ram.}
{@object Piercing Ram|AETH|Piercing Ram.}
{@object Grappling Ram|AETH|Grappling Ram}

entries.name: {@object Flamethrower|AETH|Flamethrower}
entries: Flamethrowers are excellent for creating havoc on the ship at the other end by damaging crew and igniting fires on the ship. Their flammable ammunition is succeptible to detonation, which makes them a risk to have aboard.

entries.name: Armament Properties
entries: {@b Turreted.} A turreted armament can fire in any direction, regardless of ship heading.
{@b Armored.} All crew members manning this armament gain +4 to their AC.

{@b Explosive.} Armament with the Explosive property deals area damage on impact to both ship and crew. If an armament with the explosive property is destroyed, it immediately deals a critical hit on its position and the armament is unrepairable. If no radius is specified, any damage or effects occur in a 5-foot-radius.
{@b Siege.} Deals double damage against structures. Does not apply to ships.
{@b Impact.} When an armament with Impact hits, all crew on the ship struck must make a DC 15 DEX save or be unable to move or use armament until next turn.

{@b Tether.} When a vehicle is tethered it cannot use its movement to move farther from your ship. Once on each of your ship's turns thereafter, your crew may spend 2 crew actions to use the ship harpoon again, reeling the tethered ship closer by 1 hex. If this action pulls the ship into your hex, that ship is now grappled by you. The tethered ship may break the tether by destroying the harpoon, rope, or weapon.
{@b Ramming Speed.} To use a ram, your ship must move 1 full hex in a straight line before entering the same space of the target vehicle.
{@b Fire.} When this armament hits a ship, a fire is started on that ship. A crewmember must use their action to put out the flame.

{@b Grapple.} When you hit a vehicle with this armament, the struck vehicle is automatically grappled. If a percentage value is attached to this property, roll a percentile die. If the roll is higher than the value then the grapple succeeds. Otherwise, the grapple fails.

entries.name: The Common Law
entries: The common law is a code honored by almost every sailor of the aether. These laws are culturally engrained and common sense for any aetherfaring crew, and anyone found to have violated the common law will be held in the lowest regard by their fellow sailors.

items: Surrendered crew shall not be executed and shall not be marooned except with good prospect of survival.
The right of Parley shall be respected.
Mutiny without just cause is punishable by death.
A commander who subjects their crew to cruel or unjust treatment shall be punished proportionally.
Anyone who helps recover another person's ship or cargo is entitled to commensurate reward. If no person has claim to the ship or cargo, they who recover it may take it as salavage.
Living persons shall not be jettisoned into aether and abandoned.

entries.name: The right of Parley
entries: When invoked, the right of Parley compels two opposing sides in a dispute to engage in talks under truce until negotiations have concluded. The side that calls for Parley can send one representative and the negotiations are to take place where most comfortable for the obliged party (normally on their ship). Parley does not guarantee compromise or agreement -- just that honest negotiations can occur.

There are limitations to invoking Parley: If combat is already engaged, the time for Parley has passed; If you've already been heard out by the crew and the situation hasn't changed, the time for Parley has passed; If the situation has changed such that safe negotiations seem unfeasible, the time for Parley has passed (or is yet to come!).

entries.name: Factions in the Known World
entries: Too many factions to count exist throughout Pelor's Disc.  The following are just the most well-known.

entries.name: The Alliance
entries: The Alliance was created in response to new factions emerging off-world that were unimpressed by a lone nation's power. Initially only comprised of three prominent nations from a single Erathian continent, the Alliance soon came to represent half of Erathis. Historians believe that, had they not arrogantly instigated and then lost the Sehanine War against Arlleuad, they would have gone on to control all of Erathis.

entries.name: Arlleuad
entries: The high elves and eladrin of Arlleuad (pronounced Are-lay-odd) proved themselves as a powerful nation after defeating the burgeoning Alliance in what people of Erathis call the Sehanine War. Despite their wartime prowess, however, Arlleuad has sought to establish itself as a city of commerce and arts, much to the dismay of the Coalition of Melora who would prefer them be a buffer between the Alliance and deeper space.

entries.name: Gwe-cythraul
entries: The Drow of Gwe-cythraul (pronounced Gway-keth-isle) seem to exist for the singular goal of serving Lolth. Currently in a war against the Raven Queen's shadar-kai, Drow of Gwe-cythraul are still known to roam the aether, often raiding passerby ships in search of sacrifices to Lolth. Those brave enough to break bread with worshippers of Lolth may make port amongst their towering gothic castles, although few are so naive as to do so.

entries.name: Coalition of Melora
entries: Self-described freedom fighters, the Coalition of Melora is a decentralized alliance amongst the factions beyond Sehanine that seeks to assert themselves as an independent region. Unofficially headquartered in Port Avandara (the farthest inhabited point from Erathis), the Coalition has been broadly unsuccessful in furthering their goals. Nonetheless, they stand as the single largest faction in the outer disc and have yet to be usurped, although some have tried.

entries.name: The Iounian Order
entries: The Iounian Order is a secluded organization of scholars, mages, and clerics of Ioun dedicated to unearthing and understanding the secrets of the Known World. Their headquarters is famously located within an unending and seemingly inpenetrable arcane storm, just one aspect of the Order that contriubtes to their enigmatic reputation.

entries.name: Goblin Balls
entries: Goblin balls are better known for their part in humorous minstrel tales and embellished heroic stories than for their actual, more sinister nature. Goblin balls begin as an amalgamation of ship parts conglomerated by a cult of goblins with motive unknown. Over time, debris falls into the ball's gravitational field as more ship parts are added until the ball grows to rival the size of some asteroids. As their size grows, so too do the powers within. Each goblin ball devotes itself to the worship of a single being that they deify and seek to serve at all costs.

entries.name: Races in Aetherscape
entries: Every race has a unique place in the universe. The following are just some of the setting-speficic aspects of races as a jumping-off point.

{@b High & Eladrin Elves.} Over the millenia many elves have learned to call Erathis home but soon after the advent of aetherflight, many of the high elf enclaves made pilgrimage to Sehanine and started anew. Upon arrival, some high elves chose to live in the Feywild. Their descendants, known as the eladrin, now often venture from the feywild to the material plane in their youth to explore and understand the echo of their world. Despite being relatively new, Arlleuad, the high elf capital city, is well known from the Salts of Drum to Port Avandara.

{@b Drow & Shadar-Kai Elves.} While most peoples know the larger moon as Sehanine, the Drow know it as Nghysgod (giss-god). Just as the High Elves did, the Drow quickly voyaged from Erathis to their ancestral home, but with the intention of creating a nation fully devoted to Lolth. Gwe-cythraul (Gway-keth-isle) stands as a monument to Lolth and the drow who inhabit the city live fully immersed in Lolth's dogma. The Drow have little interest in the Shadowfell but the Raven Queen who rules over the Shadowfell has taken great offense to their sacrilege so close to her domain. The shadar-kai, servants to the Raven Queen, wage war against the Drow to stop their affronts to her realm.

{@b Dwarves.} Most dwarves still call Erathis their home, but the rich prospects of a life amongst the stars has driven many a dwarf away from their underground dwellings. As it turns out, life in a ship isn't much different from life in the mines, and the asteroids of Tharizdun's disc have riches aplenty.

{@b Rock gnomes.} Artificers at heart, these inventive gnomes took quickly to the stars, proving exceptionally gifted towards repairing and maintaining ships, as well as innovating new modifications to be installed. When your battered and bruised airship pulls into a shipyard and a rock gnome steps up to the task, you know you're in good hands.
{@b Warforged.} Believed to be the hand-made creations of Moradin himself, warforged are an extremely rare sight often interpreted as a holy omen to worshippers of Moradin.

{@b Goblins.} Although goblins are rarely seen in cities, towns, or ship crews, their reputation amongst the stars is secured. Not particularly liked, and often joked about with a punchline ending in 'goblin balls', goblins who do find their way into civilization are nevertheless appreciated on any crew for their natural proclivity for sneaking.

{@b Firbolgs.} Stronger than a bear and taller than a goliath, firbolgs have features similar to humans, often with red or blonde hair, thick beards, and fair skin. A firbolg's ancestors are said to have originated from Sehanine and, much like the high elves, returned there through aetherflight. Although firbolgs tend to prefer solitude with nature, the firbolg clans are infamous amongst the Alliance for their role in the Battle of Heddwech Valley during the Sehanine War, where an entire invasion batallion was repelled by them in an extremely pyrrhic victory. It's often told that during this battle, Claio Stonepetal sundered an armored frigate in two with a single swing of his claymore.

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A {@item holy symbol|phb} (a gift to you when you entered the priesthood), a prayer {@item book|phb} or prayer wheel, 5 sticks of incense, vestments, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15 gp

entries.name: The Flames of Pelor
entries: Some who worship Pelor are chosen to leave their temples and travel beyond the farthest reaches of Pelor's light to spread his virtue and illuminate even the darkest regions of the aether. These acolytes are the Flames of Pelor, an order whose mission is well-known throughout the Known World. Your Shelter the Faithful feature will grant you welcome in any good-aligned deity's temple.

entries.name: Feature: Shelter of the Faithful
entries: As a flame of Pelor, you command the respect of not only those who share your faith, but all those who worship good deities. You can perform the religious ceremonies of your deity and you and your adventuring companions can expect to receive free healing and care at a temple, shrine, or other established presence that worships a good-aligned deity, though you must provide any material components needed for spells. Worshippers of good-aligned deities will support you (but only you) at a modest lifestyle.

You might also have ties to a specific temple dedicated to your chosen deity or pantheon, and you have a residence there. This could be the temple where you used to serve, if you remain on good terms with it, or a temple where you have found a new home. While near your temple, you can call upon the priests for assistance, provided the assistance you ask for is not hazardous and you remain in good standing with your temple.

_.displayName: scroll case stuffed full of notes from your studies or prayers

_: One tool kit of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A {@item Map or Scroll Case|phb|scroll case} stuffed full of notes from your studies or prayers, a winter {@item blanket|phb}, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, a {@table Tools|phb|tool of your choice}, and 5 gp

entries.name: Witness of Tharizdun
entries: You've delved deeper into Tharizdun's Disc than anyone else and somehow lived to tell the tale. You saw something in there that not even Pelor's light could reach and it's changed you. Perhaps it was just a hallunication of madness, but it felt real. Whatever you saw, it's your choice whether to share your discovery or keep it a secret.

entries.name: Feature: Alien Discovery
entries: The exact nature of this discovery depends on the nature of your seclusion. It might be a great truth about the cosmos, the deities, the powerful beings of the outer planes, or the forces of nature. It could be a site that no one else has ever seen. You might have uncovered a fact that has long been forgotten, or unearthed some relic of the past that could rewrite history.
It may even be something utterly unfatomable altogether.
Work with your DM to determine the details of your discovery and its impact on the campaign.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: What was the reason you delved deep into Tharizdun's Disc, and what will you do now with your new knowledge? You can work with your DM to determine the exact nature of your seclusion, or you can choose or roll on the table below to determine the reason behind your travels.

rows: I was searching for spiritual enlightenment.
I was partaking of communal living in accordance with the dictates of a religious order.
I was exiled for a crime I didn't commit.
I retreated from society after a life-altering event.
I needed inspiration for my art, literature, music, or manifesto.
I needed to commune with nature, far from civilization.
I was the caretaker of an ancient ruin or relic.
I didn't believe the stories told of Tharizdun's Disc and wanted to see for myself.

_.special: letter from a dead colleague posing a question you have not yet been able to answer

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A {@item Ink (1-ounce bottle)|phb|bottle of black ink}, a quill, a small knife, a letter from a dead colleague posing a question you have not yet been able to answer, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp

entries.name: Scholar of the Iounian Order
entries: The Iounian order is a secluded organization of scholars, mages, and clerics of Ioun dedicated to unearthing and understanding the secrets of the Known World. As a scholar in this order, you have dedicated yourself to this goal and now find yourself traveling the lands in search of ancient and forgotten places, artifacts, and knowledge.

entries.name: Feature: Researcher
entries: When you attempt to learn or recall a piece of lore, if you do not know that information, you often know where and from whom you can obtain it. Usually, this information comes from a library, scriptorium, university, or a sage or other learned person or creature. Your DM might rule that the knowledge you seek is secreted away in an almost inaccessible place, or that it simply cannot be found. Unearthing the deepest secrets of the multiverse can require an adventure or even a whole campaign.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: Iounian scholars study a variety of fields. To determine the nature of your scholarly training, roll a d8 or choose from the options in the table below.

_.special: trophy taken from a fallen enemy (a dagger, broken blade, or piece of a banner)

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: One type of {@filter gaming set|items|source=phb|miscellaneous=mundane|type=gaming set}, {@filter vehicles (land)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (land)}

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: An insignia of rank, a trophy taken from a fallen enemy (a {@item dagger|phb}, broken blade, or piece of a banner), a bone {@item dice set|phb} or {@item playing card set|phb}, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp

entries.name: Alliance Marine (Soldier)
entries: The Alliance marines have been your life for as long as you could hold a sword. You might have served on airships and fought off invaders on the outer edge of Erathis or been a member of the infamous Vanguard during the Sehanine War. Or perhaps you were just a customs enforcer at a port. Whatever your story, you have good standing with the Alliance marines and will find respect amongst them.

entries.name: Feature: Military Rank
entries: You have a military rank from your career as a soldier. Soldiers loyal to your former military organization still recognize your authority and influence, and they defer to you if they are of a lower rank. You can invoke your rank to exert influence over other soldiers and requisition simple equipment or horses for temporary use. You can also usually gain access to friendly military encampments and fortresses where your rank is recognized.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: During your time as a soldier, you had a specific role to play in your unit or army. Roll a d8 or choose from the options in the table below to determine your role:

table.name: Ship Crit
rows: All crew must make a DC15 DEX save or be knocked prone. Prone crewmembers must spend all their movement to stand up.

The attack automatically hits and damages a random crewmember as well. The hit crewmember does not take critical hit damage. If there is no attack when this effect occurs, a random crewmember takes 1d12 bludgeoning damage.

A fire starts somewhere in the ship, dealing 1 Hull Damage at the start of your turn. Increases by 1 damage each round as it spreads. A crewmember can use their action to attempt to put it out by making a DC 10 Dexterity check.
A random ship weapon is destroyed.
The cargo bay is penetrated. Lose 1d6 tons of cargo from your cargo bay.

feat.name: Gunner (Aetherscape)
entries: You have a quick hand and keen eye when employing firearms, granting you the following benefits:

items: Increase your Dexterity score by 1, to a maximum of 20.
You gain proficiency with firearms (see "{@variantrule Firearms|DMG}" in the Dungeon Master's Guide).
You ignore the loading property of firearms.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls.

entries: While manning ship armament, you count as 2 crewmembers for the purposes of operating that armament. If the crew requirement is 1, you can still only make 1 attack per turn.

feat.name: Artificer Initiate (Aetherscape)
entries: You've learned some of an artificer's inventiveness:

items: You learn one cantrip of your choice from the {@filter artificer spell list|spells|level=0;1|class=artificer}, and you learn one 1st-level spell of your choice from {@filter that list|spells|level=0;1|class=artificer}. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
You can cast this feat's 1st-level spell without a spell slot, and you must finish a long rest before you can cast it in this way again. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

You gain proficiency with one type of {@filter artisan's tools|items|type=artisan's tools} of your choice, and you can use that type of tool as a spellcasting focus for any spell you cast that uses Intelligence as its spellcasting ability.

entries: You can attempt to repair magical items with your artisan's tools.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Aether Sails
entries: {@i +2 Movement, Aether only. 150gp per ton.}

Aether sails require no power, however these translucent and shimmering sails can only catch the ethereal currents that flow throughout the Aether. Although not nearly as impressive as other methods of Aetherflight-capable propulsion, these sails are reliable and an ideal backup.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Aetherite Pylons
entries: {@i +4 Movement, Requires 2 Power, Levitation, Aether only. 1500gp per ton.}

When power is sent into the these translucent, colorful crystals, they produce a levitation effect. In aetherspace, the effect is amplified into propulsion. These fliers are coveted for their value, capability, and near-indestructability.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Cloth Sails
entries: {@i +1 Movement, Atmosphere only. 50gp per ton.}
Simple sails as on a boat, these bundles of fabric catch the wind and pull the craft forward. Useful for water- and atmospheric- travel, but useless in the Aether.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Paddle Wheel
entries: {@i +3 Movement, Requires 2 Power, Levitation. 400gp per ton.}
A magical paddle wheel of artificer design capable of churning water, air and aether. Paddle wheels hit a sweet spot between capability and affordability.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Winged Oars
entries: {@i +4 Movement, 2 rowers per ton. 100gp per oar.}
Magical oars can propel a ship forward at impressive speed. A ship equipped for oar-power requires a number of rowers equal to two times the tonnage of the ship.
Ships using winged oars have a travel pace of 3 Movement. That speed can increase to 4 Movement, but crew must abide by forced march rules.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Wings
entries: {@i +5 Movement, Requires 1 power per 4 tons, Levitation. 2200gp per ton.}
A set of wings on a ship is efficient on small vessels, and a symbol of power and wealth on larger craft. Elegant, fast, and reliable, wings may take any form imagination can conjure.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Elemental Tether
entries: {@i +4 Movement, Requires no power, Levitation. 13,000gp.}

Elemental tethers bind an air or fire elemental and uses its power to propel the ship. Power must be applied to maintain the tether, which lasts 12h without power until it is dispelled and the elemental freed. The elemental type used grants the according property from the life-support ship modification.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Furnace
entries: {@i +2 Power, requires 4 tons of fuel per month of operation. 2000 gp.}

Normally powered by coal, wood, or some other flammable substance, furnaces are a very common and accessible power source. Due to the cargo space required to store the fuel, furnaces are rarely seen in trade or expedition vessels. 4 tons of fuel are required to power a furnace for 1 month.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Astral Nexus
entries: {@i +4 Power, requires an aetherite crystal worth at least 20,000gp. 6000 gp}

An astral Nexus requires an extremely pure piece of Aetherite to extract power from the Astral plane. The result is a very potent power source with the only downside being the actual obtaining of an Aetherite chunk of sufficient quality and dependence on said Aetherite.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Elven Conduit
entries: Elves of the moon utilize the power of dreams to traverse the Aether. A Conduit connects the dreams of elves in Trance and converts them to power. To generate 3 power, 3 elves must be in Trance with the Conduit, and 3 more elves for each power thereafter. Being in Trance in this way is mentally taxing and does not confer the benefits of a rest.
The Conduit itself generally takes the form of something natural, like a tree or monolithic rock, whose material extends throughout the ship, giving Elvish ships an organic or natural appearance.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Artifurnace
entries: An artifurnace functions similarly to a mundane furnace but requires magic items as fuel. One non-consumable magic item will power a furnace for one month, and power output depends on the rarity of the magic item.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Gemforge
entries: Powered by energy from dematerializing valuable gemstones, gemforges were first created by the collaborative craftsmanship of dwarves and gnomes and are renowned for their high output and compact fuel source. Gemforges are powered based on the gold value of the gems put in, as seen in the table below.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Echo Pool
entries: This clear pool of magic extends the effect of Detect Magic, Detect Thoughts, or Detect Evil and Good over a 10-mile radius sphere for 24h but in turn greatly weakens the effect of the spell. {@spell Detect Thoughts} will only sense the presence and direction of intelligent thought (5+ INT) from off the ship and the pool will turn orange. {@spell Detect Magic} will similarly only detect the presence and direction of magic, turning purple. {@spell Detect Evil and Good} will not provide a direction but will turn black when detecting evil and white when detecting good.
A spell slot must be expended when casting a spell into the pool, and the caster gains no benefit from the spell.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Stripping
entries: {@i +1 Movement, -2 AC. 100 gp per ton.}
This process removes non-essential weight from the ship's hull, increasing speed but reducing integrity in turn.
Reverting this process costs 120 gp per ton, representing the cost of material in addition to skilled labor.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Elemental Life Support
entries: {@i -1 Power, 2000 gp.}

This contraption contains one minor air elemental and one minor fire elemental. Pipes then distribute heat and breathable air throughout the ship. Power is required to extract and distribute air and heat from the elementals. Necessary for extended voyages where air and heat may be scarce.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Aetherite Implements
entries: {@i +1 Movement, -1 Power, Levitation, Aether only. 500 gp per ton.}
Although too weak to propel the ship on their own, when these small Aetherite crystals are powered they assist a ship in Aetherflight.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Adamantium Plating
entries: {@i +2 AC, -1 Movement. 1000 gp per ton.}

Similar to iron plating but with the strength of (nonmagical) adamantite, a ship equipped with this plating is immune to critical hits from armament or crew. The ship must still roll on the Ship Crit table when reduced to 50%.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Mithral Plating
entries: {@i +2 AC. 1000 gp per ton.}
As strong as iron but as light as wood, this (nonmagical) mithril plating provides the benefits of heavier armor without the reduction in speed.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Increased Thickness
entries: {@i +1 AC, -20% Cargo Space. 100 gp per ton.}
The hull is reinforced with extra material, decreasing cargo space by 20%. Ships with no cargo space are incapable of installing this upgrade. Hull thickness can only be increased one time.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Iron Plating
entries: {@i +2 AC, -1 Movement. 300 gp per ton.}
Heavy iron armor is added to the exterior of the ship giving it a true 'ironclad' appearance.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Earthen Hull
entries: {@i -1 Movement.}
The ships hull was crafted with essence of the Plane of Earth and bears the appearance of rough slate.

As an action, a crewmember can speak this hull's command word to fortify the ship's hull by producing layers of thick stone. For 1 minute, the ship gains 3 temporary hull points and has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage. The ships movement speed is halved for the duration.

If a ship with this hull type is landed on solid stone for 8 hours, it will begin to repair any critical damage it has sustained. Thereafter, the ship repairs 1 hull point for every 4 uninterrupted hours it remains in this state, although it cannot repair above half of its maximum hull points in this way.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Feywild Timber Hull
entries: The ships hull is made from ancient trees of the Feywild and carries from them strange, transient properties.

As an action, a crewmember can speak this hull's command word to change its appearance to resemble any hull of the activating creatures choice, including hulls of different materials, although the basic shape of the ship can't be altered (e.g., a galleon can't be disguised as a cog). When this glamour is not active, the hull has a rich burnt umber color that seems to glimmer faintly in light.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Nondetection Hull
entries: The ships hull is warded against divination, with faintly sparkling diamond dust and thin layers of lead worked into the wood. The ship itself cannot be found by an echo pool or with spells like the locate object spell, and creatures aboard the ship have advantage on their saving throws against divination magic.
This modification softenes the hull, reducing its ability to deflect or absorb attacks from armament.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Glacial Hull
entries: {@i  AC.}
Thick, glacial ice forms the hull of the ship. Any creature onboard a ship with this hull installed is subjected to {@hazard extreme cold}.
This modification softenes the hull, reducing its ability to deflect or absorb attacks from armament.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Sphinx Figurehead
entries: This carved stone figurehead depicts the humanoid-lion features of a noble androsphinx with brilliant diamond eyes.

As an action, the ship can activate this item to reverse the flow of time around the ship, undoing any damage to its hull or armament that occurred since the start of your ship's last turn. This effect can repair physical features of the ship (such as destroyed armament or masts), but doesnt restore spent resources such as ammunition, components, or items.

Once you use this ability, the diamond eyes of the sphinx crumble to dust and this ability can't be used again until 10 minutes have passed and two new diamonds, each worth at least 1,000gp, are inserted into the eye sockets.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Abjurer Figurehead
entries: This painted wood carving depicts a wise wizard gazing forward with purpose. In one arm it appears to be holding a spellbook while the other arm is raised forward with palm open, as if extending a warning.

Any creature can cast an Abjuration spell of 1st level or higher into the figurehead, touching the figurehead as the spell is cast. The spell has no effect, other than to be stored in the figurehead. The figure can store one spell at a time. If the figurehead can't hold the spell, the spell is expended wihtout effect.

Any crewmember aboard the ship can activate the figurehead to use the spell stored within. The spell uses the slot level, spell save DC, spell attack bonus, and spellcasting ability of the original caster, but is otherwise treated as if you cast the spell. The spell cast from the figurehead is no longer stored in it, freeing up space for another spell.

A spell with a range of touch can only target the ship, and a spell with a range of self can only target the ship itself. If a spell would have no effect when applied to the ship, it fails and has no effect but is still consumed.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Boar Figurehead
entries: This wooden figurehead depicts a great boar seemingly charging out of the woodwork with two rubies for eyes that glint with wild fury.

When you activate this figurehead as an action, a giant spectral boar envelops the front half of your ship and charges forward. Until your next turn, your ship's Movement increases by 2 for the turn and this figurehead counts as a {@object Blunt Ram|AETH|} for your ship.

Once you use this ability, the boar's ruby eyes crumble to dust and this ability can't be used again until 1 hour has passed and two new rubies, each worth at least 500 gp, are inserted into the eye sockets.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Octopus Figurehead
entries: This wooden figurehead depicts a giant octopus with tentacles outstretched. In its eye sockets, two sapphires gleam with the fervor of the tide.

You can activate this figurehead as an action, releasing a giant spectral octopus that envelops the front half of your ship as its ghostly tentacles lash out. For the next minute, this figurehead counts as a {@object Grappling Ram|AETH|} for your ship.
While this figurehead is active, you can prematurely end its effect to create a smoke cloud with a radius of 500 feet that lasts for 1 minute. Everything inside the area is heavily obscured.

Once you use this ability, the octopus's sapphire eyes crumble to dust and this ability can't be used again until 1 hour has passed and two new sapphires, each worth at least 1000 gp, are inserted into the eye sockets.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Fortified Armaments
entries: {@i 500gp per armament.}
Fortifying an armament grants it the armored property, found {@book here.|AETH|2|Armament Properties}

vehicleUpgrade.name: Turret Mounts
entries: {@i 250gp per armament.}
You can install a rotating turret for armament and grant that armament the turreted property, found {@book here.|AETH|2|Armament Properties}.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Alchemist's Lab
entries: {@i Test tubes, piping, alembics, and jars fill the room. The smell of dried herbs and spilt tinctures fill the air as a cauldron bubbles atop an open flame.}
Alchemist's supplies and an herbalism kit are always considered to be present while working in this room, and any checks made with these tools are done with advantage if the user has proficiency.

Furthermore, when mixing potions in this room per the DMG rules on {@book Mixing Potions|DMG|7|Variant: Mixing Potions}, you may reroll 1's when rolling on the {@table Variant: Mixing Potions; Potion Miscibility} if you are proficient with alchemist's supplies.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Assassin's Garden
entries: {@i A warm and humid air suspends itself amongst the vine stalks and beds of soil, conjuring images of a lush jungle that belies a much deadlier purpose.}
A Poisoner's Kit is always considered to be present while working in this room, and any checks made with the kit is done with advantage if the user has proficiency.

This room is carefully crafted to facilitate the cultivation of toxic botanicals that you can use in poisons. Successfully cultivating a crop with a desired toxicity requires a source (seeds or spores), time (at least 1 month) and a series of successful Intelligence (Nature) check (to determine the crop size). Then, the poison must be crafted via Xanathar's {@variantrule Downtime Activity: Crafting an Item|XGE} rules.
Note: These rules are WIP for now so talk with DM about the specific values and types of growable poisons.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Arcane Library
entries: {@i Bookshelves cover every wall in the room. Books of all shapes and sizes line the shelves and stacks of large tomes pile up from the floor. Behind the scent of musty books is the faint smell of ink.}

This room counts as a well-stocked library. Additionally, when the room is built you can choose a school of magic. When copying new spells of this school of magic into your spellbook, you can halve the time required to copy that spell if you are not already benefitting from a time reduction.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Shrine
entries: {@i No more than a humble chapel with room for a small congregation, religious imagery of a single deity sits on an altar to one end. As you enter, a comforting presence fills the room as you think you hear a faint, resonating hymn.}

Wisdom (Religion) checks made here that appeal to the deity that the chapel is associated with have advantage. The material cost of spells that bring the dead to life is halved when cast inside this room.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Tailor's Workshop
entries: {@i An eclectic assortment of textiles and unfinished projects hang off the walls. The room is warmly lit and harkens back to a pastoral lifestyle as buckets of yarn skirt a towering loom at the center.}

Weaver's tools, Leatherworker's tools, and a Disguise kit are always considered to be present while working in this room. The time required to complete projects using these tools is halved, and any checks using these tools are made with advantage if the user has proficiency.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Forge
entries: {@i The bellowing roar of the fire, the hiss of escaping steam, and the twang of metal create a steady symphony of production. A lone anvil beside a bucket of water dominates the room as the radiant heat of the furnace draws sweat.}

Smith's tools and Glassblower's tools are always considered to be present while working in this room. If proficient with smith's tools or glassblower's tools, you can use this room to craft any metal or glass item, respectively, from the {@table Adventuring Gear|PHB} table in addition to metal items off the {@table Weapons|PHB} or {@table Armor and Shields; Armor|PHB} table. The cost and time required to craft items in this way follows the Xanathar's downtime rules for {@variantrule Downtime Activity: Crafting an Item|XGE|crafting an item}.
This room can be built in the same area as a {@vehupgrade Furnace|AETH}. If it is, the cost of this room is reduced by 1500 gp.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Galley
entries: {@i Hot aromatic steam floats about the room, dampening the sound of sizzling fire and bubbling stew. Pots, pans, and jars of ingredients clutter the shelves while a cutting board rests like a runway to the cauldron below.}

This room is a well-stocked kitchen, not to be confused with the class of ship called a galley. Cook's utensils are always considered to be present while working in this room, and any checks using these tools are made with advantage if the user has proficiency. Meals prepared for a crew in this room require half as many ingredients to make.

vehicleUpgrade.name: Brig
entries: {@i Thick iron bars separate a squalid, empty cell from the rest of the room.}

This room is equipped to hold one small or medium humanoid per 5 feet of area. The room is non-magical and the jail cell door is bound by a large lock (DC 20 to open). If a crewmember is acting as warden and providing a prisoner with food and care, their Charisma checks towards that prisoner are made with advantage.

object.name: Blunt Ram
entries: {@b Siege, Ramming Speed, Impact.}
Rams are devices mounted to the front of a ship, taking place of the figurehead spot.

hitEntries: 1 bludgeoning hull damage per 10 tons of ship.

object.name: Piercing Ram
entries: {@b Ramming Speed, Grapple (50%).}
Rams are devices mounted to the front of a ship, taking place of the figurehead spot.

hitEntries: 1 piercing hull damage per 10 tons of ship.

object.name: Grappling Ram
entries: {@b Ramming Speed, Grapple.}
Rams are devices mounted to the front of a ship, taking place of the figurehead spot.

object.name: Light Ballista
entries: {@b Turreted.}
A ballista is a large crossbow that fires bolts. It takes one action to load, aim, and fire the light ballista.

attackEntries: {@hit +6} to hit, range 400/800 ft., one target.

object.name: Heavy Ballista
entries: {@b Turreted.}
A heavy ballista is a massive crossbow that fires heavy bolts. Before it can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes one action to load the weapon and one action to aim and fire it.

attackEntries: {@hit +8} to hit, range 400/1000 ft., one target.

object.name: Mangonel
entries: {@b Siege.}

A mangonel is a type of catapult that hurls heavy projectiles in a high arc. This payload can hit targets behind cover. Before the mangonel can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes one actions to load the weapon and one action to aim it and fire it.

attackEntries: {@hit +5} to hit, range 400/1000 ft., (can't hit targets within 60 feet of it), one target.

object.name: Catapult
entries: {@b Siege.}

A catapult hurls large projectiles great distances in a high arc. This payload can hit targets behind cover. Before the catapult can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes one action to load the weapon, one action to aim it, and one action to fire it.
A catapult typically hurls a heavy stone. However, it can launch other kinds of projectiles, such as barrels of oil or sewage, with different effects.

attackEntries: {@hit +4} to hit, range 500/1200 ft., (can't hit targets within 60 feet of it), one target.

object.name: Flamethrower
entries: {@b Fire, Explosive.}
Flamethrowers launch projectile flame towards enemies, damaging crew and igniting flames. It takes 1 action to aim and fire the flamethrower.

actionEntries.name: Flame
entries: The flamethrower propels flames in a 200-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw or take 3d8 fire damage. A flammable object caught in the area ignites if it isn't being worn or carried.

object.name: Jettison
entries: Jettisons are similar to catapults but are designed to launch a bundle of shrapnel as anti-crew projectiles that are ideal against crowded decks but ineffective against hulls. Before the jettison can be fired it must be loaded and aimed. It takes one action to load and aim it, and one action to fire it.
A jettison typically launches small pieces of sharp shrapnel. However, it can launch other kinds of projectiles, such as bundles of sling bullets, with different effects.

actionEntries.name: Shrapnel
entries: Any creature within this armanent's area of effect must make a (DC15) DEX saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 3d4}) bludgeoning damage on a failure.

object.name: Light Cannon
entries: {@b Explosive (5-foot-radius).

Cannons as feared by the enemy as they are by their own crew. Terrifyingly powerful in combat both against crew and hull, cannons have a troublesome tendency to explode when destroyed. Before a light cannon can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes one action to load and aim it, and one action to fire it.

A cannon typically fires shells filled with explosives that deal area damage on impact. However, it can fire other kinds of projectiles, such as round shot (a full-metal ball), with different effects.

attackEntries: {@hit +6} to hit, range 600/1400 ft., one target.
{@hit +6} to hit, range 400/1000 ft., one target.
hitEntries: Any creature caught in the blast must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage on a fail or half as much on a success.
